Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of a Novel Surgeon-Placed Adductor Canal Block in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either the novel ACB technique or a standard single-shot ACB by anesthesia.

Participants.evidence: 56 consecutive patients undergoing primary TKA by a single surgeon.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either the novel ACB technique or a standard single-shot ACB by anesthesia.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates a novel surgeon-placed adductor canal block (ACB) with catheter placement for continuous regional nerve block, aiming to reduce pain and opioid use post-TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was perioperative pain measured by a visual analog scale (VAS) over seven days postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved through consecutive patient presentation.

Blinding.evidence: no blinding of patients or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted between July and November 2017, involving 56 consecutive patients.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Forty-eight patients initiated the survey, and 36 completed it.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The novel ACB group showed a 25% reduction in VAS pain scores (3.9 to 2.9), a 24% reduction in opioid use, and significant reductions in side effects compared to the control group.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in the novel ACB group.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
